source: This approach has meant that once interest rates reach or approach zero, central banks have little choice but to activate large asset-purchase programs that are supposed to stimulate demand.
translation:
Translate the following text from en to kk: This approach has meant that once interest rates reach or approach zero, central banks have little choice but to activate large asset-purchase programs that are supposed to stimulate demand. However, this may not be enough in the long run because it is difficult for the government to control inflation and monetary policy.
This approach also means that if a country's central bank decides to sell its currency at an exchange rate higher than the market price of the currency, then it will reduce its own money supply and the purchasing power of the currency.
The situation can lead to inflationary pressures on the economy, which can make the central bank's ability to control inflation difficult.
It seems that the main reason why countries choose to engage in such policies is to avoid the risk of inflation, but I would argue that it is not always the case. In some cases, countries might actually benefit from these policies. For example, when a country experiences hyperinflation, it may become more stable economically by reducing inflation pressure.
In summary, it appears that there is no single answer to the question whether countries should engage in such policies. It depends on many factors, including the economic situation of the country and the specific circumstances involved. The decision must be made based on careful consideration of
reference: Бұл тәсілдің ерекшелігі – пайыздық үстемелер нөлге жақындағанда орталық банктердің сұранысты арттыру үшін активтерді сатып алу бағдарламаларын іске қосудан басқа амалы қалмайды.

source: For starters, households have not responded to ultra-low interest rates by saving less and spending more.
translation:
Translate the following text from en to kk: For starters, households have not responded to ultra-low interest rates by saving less and spending more. This is because households do not want to be stuck in a situation where they cannot borrow money to buy goods or services. The other option that has not been considered yet is that some people are simply too scared of the future to spend money.
For example, if you see an advertisement for something you really like but it's too expensive, you might decide to save your money instead of buying it. This could happen with many different types of products and services, including things like clothes, furniture, electronics, and even food.
However, this does not mean that all consumers will always choose to avoid spending money altogether. There are still some people who may prefer to save their money rather than spend it. These individuals may be motivated by various factors such as personal values, financial goals, or the desire to build up a savings account.
In conclusion, while ultra-low interest rates can encourage households to save more and spend less, it is important to consider other factors that may influence consumer behavior. It is also crucial to ensure that any measures taken to reduce consumer spending align with broader economic goals and objectives. Additionally, policymakers should carefully evaluate the potential consequences of

source: It’s easy to see why, despite the data, predetermined formulas are attractive to monetary policymakers. The prevailing wisdom holds that in order to return the inflation rate to a preferred level, any slack in the economy must be eliminated.
translation: Translate the following text from en to kk: It’s easy to see why, despite the data, predetermined formulas are attractive to monetary policymakers. The prevailing wisdom holds that in order to return the inflation rate to a preferred level, any slack in the economy must be eliminated. This is an example of what economists call “the zero lower bound.” The idea behind this theory is that the government can only use its authority to eliminate slack if it has no other way to do so. As long as there is money and credit available, the government will have a way to reduce inflation without eliminating slack. In fact, the government has already done just that with some frequency over the past few decades. In 1980, for example, the U.S. Treasury Department announced a new policy called “quantitative easing,” which involved injecting large amounts of money into the financial markets. Since then, the government has been using quantitative easing on a regular basis to stimulate the economy. In 2007, for instance, the Federal Reserve launched a series of quantitative easing programs aimed at boosting economic growth. These programs were designed to help stabilize the stock market and increase consumer spending. Quantitative easing was originally intended to be used to eliminate excess liquidity (money that banks hold in reserve)

source: While the death penalty for drugs has existed in Bangladesh for decades, it has rarely been used.

The government has been trying to change this with a new law that allows convicted drug users to receive parole (parole is a temporary release from prison) after completing their sentences and paying some fines. This was introduced by the then Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in 2014.

As a result, even if women’s wages were to increase by only 1% on average over the next decade, they would still earn about 3% less than men.

source: The truth is that it is the technological revolution and the surge in consumption in Asia – not the UK’s relationship with the EU – that will transform the way business is done over the next couple of decades.

Translate the following text from en to kk: The truth is that it is the technological revolution and the surge in consumption in Asia – not the UK’s relationship with the EU – that will transform the way business is done over the next couple of decades. As a matter of fact, China has already started to embrace its own digital economy, which will have an impact on the UK’s export markets.
The rise of China as a major global player is one of the most significant trends in recent years, driving economic growth and opening up new opportunities for businesses around the world. The UK’s relationship with the EU has been a source of tension and conflict since the Brexit referendum, but this is about to change due to the continued integration of China into the global market.
As a result, the UK must be prepared to adapt to the changing landscape of international trade and commerce, while also embracing the benefits of digital technology. This means that businesses need to stay informed about the latest developments in technology and be open to adopting new ways of doing business, such as virtual reality or augmented reality, to better serve their customers and compete in today’s highly competitive marketplace.

source: This “dementia tax,” as it became widely known, deeply offended the core constituency, the elderly, of May’s Conservative Party.
translation:
Translate the following text from en to kk: This “dementia tax,” as it became widely known, deeply offended the core constituency, the elderly, of May’s Conservative Party. In a country where most people are in their 40s and 50s, the vast majority of voters were young enough to be eligible for free healthcare, which was not available to them.
The government’s response to this issue is that they will introduce a dementia tax, which will have no effect on the current system of social security.
In a speech at the Conservative Party conference held in London on December 18th, 2017, the Prime Minister said that the government would introduce a dementia tax, which will be paid by the individual who suffers from dementia or has already developed it. The tax will amount to approximately 3% of an individual’s income.
This proposal, however, has not been fully implemented yet, as many individuals still do not have access to free healthcare.
In order to address this problem, the government has proposed several measures. Firstly, they plan to introduce a new health insurance scheme called the Alzheimer’s Society Health Insurance Scheme (AHIS). This scheme will provide a wide range of services, including mental health care, rehabilitation therapy, and other

A person who has been hurt by someone else may have learned that they are not capable of taking care of themselves or being kind enough to help others. They will likely become more selfish in their actions, as they learn that everyone deserves respect and kindness. This is especially true when it comes to family members or close friends, because these people have invested so much time and effort into them. The pain of loss and the fear of rejection can cause someone to feel like there is no way out of their own problems. This can lead to depression, anxiety, and other mental health issues. It's important to understand that hurting someone is never okay. It can make anyone very sad and lonely. We should always try to prevent such situations before they happen.
